physical_appearance:Decked in a loin cloth and a head gear
 this archer stands with his feet apart whilst drawing his bow. Dense foliage envelop him
 and its dark green hue juxtaposes the bright pink of these blossoming lotus flowers
 which are symbols of purity.

sgcool_label_text:Being the sole female participant in PERSAGI (Persatuan Ahli Gambar Indonesia or Association of Indonesian Draftsmen) 
 Emiria Soenassa is a pioneering modern artist from Indonesia.   \r\nAs a self-proclaimed princess from the island Sultanate of Tidore
 Emiria advocated for Papuan independence from the Dutch.  An archer has bow drawn
 but his aim or the source of his threat remain unknown in this work.  This
 added with the stark contrast between the dark jungle and the bright flowers in various proportion conjure up a sense of mysteriousness and unsettling quality to the work.  The ethnic origin of the subject remains ambiguous
 with certain elements of Dayak (loincloth) and Papuan (headdress and archery hunting) appear to have been combined together.  \r\n\r\n

metadata.title_text: Danger lurking behind the lotus Bahaya Belakang Kembang Terate
metadata.physical_appearance: Decked in a loin cloth and a head gear, this archer stands with his feet apart whilst drawing his bow. Dense foliage envelop him, and its dark green hue juxtaposes the bright pink of these blossoming lotus flowers, which are symbols of purity.
metadata.subject_terms_1: archers loincloth headdresses  bows (tools)  flower (plant material)  indigenous people  lotus (plant, general)
metadata.subject_terms_2: Archers  Headgear Headdresses Indigenous men  Papua (Indonesia)  Lotus in art Painting
metadata.sgcool_label_text:
Being the sole female participant in PERSAGI (Persatuan Ahli Gambar Indonesia or Association of Indonesian Draftsmen) , Emiria Soenassa is a pioneering modern artist from Indonesia.   
As a self-proclaimed princess from the island Sultanate of Tidore, Emiria advocated for Papuan independence from the Dutch.  An archer has bow drawn, but his aim or the source of his threat remain unknown in this work.  This, added with the stark contrast between the dark jungle and the bright flowers in various proportion conjure up a sense of mysteriousness and unsettling quality to the work.  The ethnic origin of the subject remains ambiguous, with certain elements of Dayak (loincloth) and Papuan (headdress and archery hunting) appear to have been combined together.
